#Text=Stefano Porcari

#Text=Stefano Porcari ( early 15th century - 9 January 1453 ) was an Italian politician and humanist from Rome , known as the leader of a rebellion against Pope Nicholas V and the Papal secular authority in Rome .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Palazzo della Signoria ( Palazzo Vecchio ) , Florence
#Text=Porcari was born into a wealthy family of Rome .
#Text=He received a humanist education and became an admirer of the ancient Roman Republic .
#Text=Porcari trained as a lawyer , and in 1427 and 1428 was elected capitano del popolo of Florence under the protection of Pope Martin V .
#Text=There he met the humanist scholar Leonardo Bruni and the Camaldolese monk Ambrose Traversari .

#Text=While in Florence , it was Porcari 's habit , during public celebrations , to give speeches from a balcony on the Palazzo della Signoria , exhorting the people to honor justice , as the foundation of the commune .
#Text=He then traveled to France and Germany . [ 1 ]

#Text=After his return to Italy in 1430 , he held several positions in Italian communes such as the podestà of Bologna ( 1432 ) , Siena ( 1434 ) , Orvieto ( 1435 ) and was also governor of the fortress of Trani .
#Text=He came back to Rome under the rule of Pope Eugenius IV .
#Text=When the latter died and before the new pope was elected , he repeatedly addressed the populace to overthrow the papal rule , and to replace them by one based on the ancient Roman republic .
#Text=The new pope , Nicholas V , pardoned him , but kept him away from Rome with several assignments .

#Text=However , his participation in other plots ( including one connected with the crowning of Frederick III in Rome ) , and an inflammatory speech in the Piazza Navona against the government , led the pope to exile him to Bologna .
#Text=Roberto Cessi suggests that if this was taken as anything more than a criticism of the local city administrators , he would have been dealt with more harshly . [ 2 ]
#Text=In late December 1452 Porcari was able to escape and return to Rome .
#Text=Here he organized an insurrection whose result would be the proclamation of the Republic and , for Porcari , the title of tribune , the same held by Cola di Rienzo in the 14th century .
#Text=The action was set for the Feast of the Epiphany , 6 January 1453 , and would be backed by some three hundred mercenaries . [ 1 ]
#Text=George of Trebizond claimed to have become aware of the conspiracy , through a disaffected priest , nearly a year before and attempted to warn Pope Nicholas . [ 3 ]
#Text=Nicholas V , warned by Cardinal Basilios Bessarion that Porcari had disappeared , ordered investigations .
#Text=Porcari had planned to arrest Nicholas at Old St. Peter 's Basilica and kill members of the curia .
#Text=Among the co-conspirators were Stefano Infessura and members of the Orsini .
#Text=The conspirators were captured , including Porcari , who had tried to take shelter in the house of prince Latino Orsini .
#Text=He was subsequently tried and hanged at Castel Sant'Angelo on 9 January 1453 . [ 4 ]
#Text=Of Porcari 's literary works , sixteen concioni ( discourses ) have survived .
#Text=The description of his revolt was provided by Leon Battista Alberti in the epistle De porcario coniuratione .
